thread.title: Westfield Warringah Mall gets $310m facelift

title: Westfield Warringah Mall gets $310m facelift
text:
The first stage is expected to be open by Christmas 2016.
Sydney's northern beaches are set to get a new landmark with a $310 million facelift for the Westfield Warringah Mall shopping centre.
It will entail a new two-storey mall parallel mall, the addition of about 70 stores and a new reconfigured, smaller, Myer department store.
The remainder of the Myer space will be let to international and local fashion outlets and the ever-popular electronic devices and tablets.
Consumer demand for beauty and pampering, such as nail bars, as well as the convenience of weekend banking, will also see more given to the retailers at the expense of the diminishing "big box" department and discount department store anchors.
Advertisement The first sod of earth was turned this week at the Brookvale-based centre, with the first stage planned to open by Christmas 2016.
The mall, co-owned by Scentre​ and AMP Capital, will offer the latest in technology, dining "experiences" and entertainment, to transform the tired beach area centre into a "world class" design.
It will use the new customer systems being designed by the US-based Westfield Labs and Scentre's own invention of SmartScreens​, as well new food ordering apps and an emphasis on fresh food markets and more food outlets.
The same type of designs have been used in the upgrade of the Westfield Miranda shopping centre in Sydney's Sutherland Shire.
Scentre's chief executive Peter Allen said Westfield Warringah Mall "is a well-loved shopping centre that has long been the hub of the Northern Beaches community".
"The redevelopment will provide the local community with a curated retail environment tailored specifically to their needs," Mr Allen said.
At Scentre's half year result last month the highest rate of sales growth came from mobile phones and movies, followed by the international fashion brands, such as Zara, and food, from cafes to supermarkets.
He said the installation of technology in the shopping centres, such as Wi-Fi, has proved a boom to connect the shopper and retailer.
AMP Capital director of property Adam Tindall said AMP Capital and Scentre Group saw an opportunity to improve and expand Warringah Mall to meet a growing demand for a high quality retail offering, "as we aim to provide investors with consistent outperformance on their investment".
"This development will ensure Westfield Warringah Mall continues to serve its community while providing the opportunity to bring international large format brands to the centre," Mr Tindall said.
